conclusion: Need to analyze the acceleration-time graph to determine when the object's velocity is at its maximum.
The y-axis represents acceleration in m/s² and the x-axis represents time in seconds.
The graph shows how acceleration changes over time.
From t = 0 to t = 1 s, the acceleration is constant at +2 m/s².
From t = 1 to t = 2 s, the acceleration decreases linearly from +2 m/s² to 0 m/s².
From t = 2 to t = 3 s, the acceleration decreases further to -2 m/s².
From t = 3 to t = 4 s, the acceleration remains constant at -2 m/s².
Velocity is the integral of acceleration with respect to time.
When acceleration is positive, velocity increases; when zero, velocity remains constant; when negative, velocity decreases.
From t = 0 to t = 1 s, the velocity increases because acceleration is positive.
From t = 1 to t = 2 s, the velocity continues to increase but at a decreasing rate as acceleration decreases.
At t = 2 s, acceleration becomes zero, and the velocity reaches its peak because it stops increasing.
From t = 2 s onward, the velocity starts to decrease as acceleration becomes negative.
The velocity is at its maximum at t = 2 s, when the acceleration changes from positive to negative.
The object's velocity is at its maximum at t = 2 seconds.
